channel.name: Is there any implementation in o1js for a bigInteger provable library?

messages.content:
As I was forking the RSA implementation from an  o1js PR. I realized that the bigInteger code is not functional -> the carry overflows when proceeding to the next  limb! 
It would be helpful if there were any secure & provable implementations of a bigInteger library. In my case, a 2048-bit big integer is what is needed for `RSA65537` verification.
I think the PR is quite close to functional! I would try to make it work if I were you. Never got around to finishing it
But I think the circuit design is pretty good, I considered several strategies for implementing it with the primitives available and this should be the most efficient one

True - I managed to adapt the PR to o1js imports(it used a lot of internal functions) and make everything consistent. 
The library works but when trying to add provability assertions for limbs, it doesn't work.
An existing `bigInteger` library would solve the problem right away, that's why I am asking - otherwise I'll invest more time to make provable bigint operations work.

Yeah, we only have built-in bigints up to 256 bits right now, using ForeignField.
(They could be combined into larger bigints but that's less efficient than the design in the PR)
What do you mean with adding provability assertions here?
By adding provability, I meant adding checks after using `Provable.witness` - my bad, I should have said constraining the bigint operations
Are you saying the constraints in the PR are failing or that it fails if you add additional ones?
Trying to understand the problem, I'd really like to get this working eventually 🙂 happy to assist such efforts
I think big foreign fields would make it constantly slow -  using carry makes performance variant following the size of bigint i.e. 256-bit is as efficient as normal field operations in o1js.
Thanks @gregor :)) - let me highlight the problem better

when `res_in`  is greater than 2**128 --> res_in is subtracted by `Field.ORDER` - I understand that this is crucial so that to the next carry calculation doesn't undergo field overflow ==> this will break the algorithm!

After debugging - I realized the latter operation(overflow handling) doesn't preserve the integrity of sequential  carry computation.
```typescript
Field(res_in >> 116n)
``` always returns zero --> I just realized this actually 😅   - The later check always fails in case of `res_in` greater than 128-bit and it might be because of the  flaw using right shift. I need to check this deeper mysefl 🤔
Ok thanks, got it. The witness generation logic might have some flaw
The idea was that res_in is a multiple of 2^116, either positive or negative (modulo the field), and we want to return it divided by 2^116
True - but I think the problem is that right shifting native unsigned bigint to the right will return zero in most cases - this is what I realized might be the root of the error.

Is the 128-bit range check chosen specifically because it's a multiple of 16-bits. 
- I see that `carry.mul(1n << 116n)` can be a max size of 244 bits which is 10-bit off the upper bound of the field. 
- Adding another 16-bit will cause  overflow
- With the current o1js API - it would be easy to develop an exact bit-rangeCheck gadget but I assume it would be less efficient ==> is it related to using custom gates?
Yeah I chose the numbers to be efficiently range checkable, and fit in the field
Range checks use our custom gates yep
Bit range check would be crazy inefficient
Happy to confirm that 🙏

The line `carry = res_i.div(2n ** 116n);` solved everything - it satisfied `(xy - qp - r)_i + c_(i-1) === c_i * 2^116`
I am glad that I discussed this with you @gregor. 
Thank you 🤩
Here are the passing tests
one test case example is:
Damn this is cool. So simple 🙂
Feel free to push the fix + a test to the PR, and I'll merge and release the new APIs
Ok - I will work on it but I replaced all internal APIs to imported ones which might less efficient.
I'm happy to try if it also works with the internal APIs in the PR
For example, I used `Provable.witness` instead of `witnessFields`
Your test cases would help me a lot though 😄
The PR is 5 months old - the internal changes in the PR might cause a lot of conflicts 🤔
It's a small PR, I'll manage 🙂
Awesome! About the test - should I add a hardcoded or the generic ones based on this utility function
the generic one looks nice!

The thing is, I am adding this [dependency](https://www.npmjs.com/package/big-integer) to maintain correctness and efficiency - native JS bigint doesn't work well. If it is not a problem then, I will add it. I know that it is not good practice to use external dependencies especially in big repos such as o1js.

embeds.title: big-integer
embeds.description: An arbitrary length integer library for Javascript. Latest version: 1.6.52, last published: 5 months ago. Start using big-integer in your project by running `npm i big-integer`. There are 1461 other projects in the npm registry using big-integer.

messages.content: hm yeah I'm happy to refactor it to bigint actually, would like to avoid the dependency
we have a lot of tooling built on native bigints
but you can push it as is
with the dep
for 2048-bit bigints, I can say it doesn't work especially for `modInv` operation
we have a modular inverse impl in o1js
One last thing - Could you please refer me to a good example or guide to contribute to o1js
I am using it for preparing RSA parameters - I don't need it to be provable
I meant we have one on bigints!
Great! is there also `modPow`?

Hm good question. I guess all of the historical PRs are examples of that.

Couple of things that make a contribution better
* describe what you did in the PR description / comments
* add tests
* add a changelog entry if you change a user-facing API
* don't accidentally change formatting or other unrelated stuff 😄
But in general every contribution is welcome 😄
Should I update the used o1js API used to 0.18 as well?
Sry for the trivial questions
yeah whatever works with the code base as it is
wait let me just merge main into the PR
then it's up to date
I appreciate it!
pushed to the PR, it's up to date with main now!
Regarding bigint field arithmetic - it's internal to o1js currently. You can start with the `big-integer` lib and I'll think about a way to expose the internal crypto stack
Awesome! Thanks a lot :))
also, if you add a file for tests, you can make `rsa` a folder instead of just 1 file
I think it would be better 👍
@gregor Here is the [PR link](https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/pull/1599)

Changes


Move the existing files ./src/examples/crypto/rsa.ts to a new directory ./src/examples/crypto/rsa/rsa.ts


Fix carry computation bug in multiplication for provable Bigint2048

The constra...

messages.content: Concerning `big-integer` package, I started to adapt `modInv` & `modPow` to native bigint but I stopped after recalling that I still need the dependency to generate large prime numbers for RSA parameters.
The package has a method to return the primality of big integers based on Millerâ€“Rabin primality test and I think it would be too much work to adapt everything!
Eventually, the dependency can be no longer needed if the tests are based on hardcoded parameters rather than generic values.
In general, I would love to see `big-integer` adapted to both native bigint as well as provable `o1js`
@Florian For better context on the PR

Actually, I  began working on RSA as it's needed for the DKIM protocol in the zkEmail project for o1js.

For the time being, the RSA implementation is in the example directory, but I plan to use it for my project. 
I would like to have the implementation importable by moving it to the `crypto` or `gadgets` module in o1js. 
If that causes any inconvenience, I'll consider publishing it as an npm package or using it directly in a DKIM codebase.
I think it's a valuable addition to Gadgets, at the least the core of it (large bigint operations)
I have the Miller Rabin test on bigints in a repo somewhere and would probably copy that over to get rid of the bigint library
This is a bit late - @gregor your work is truly amazing, I learned a lot from the changes you did, and Thank you for merging the RSA example in a short time :))
